content.webTitle: NHS trusts on course to overshoot budgets by £850m, figures suggest

fields.headline: NHS trusts on course to overshoot budgets by £850m, figures suggest
fields.bodyText: NHS hospital trusts are on course to overshoot their budgets by £850m this year, more than three times the deficit health service bosses said was acceptable, research has shown. Such an overspend would be a setback for NHS England’s chief executive, Simon Stevens, and Jeremy Hunt, the health secretary, as they have pledged to ensure that trusts end the year no more than £250m in the red. The impending deficit, uncovered by the Health Service Journal, threatens to derail the agreement the NHS reached with the Treasury in July to “reset” the service’s disastrous finances this year in return for receiving £3.8bn upfront of its planned £8bn extra funding. The £850m sum emerged from figures supplied to the magazine by all but five of England’s 237 NHS trusts, now more than halfway through the service’s 2016-17 financial year, and its monitoring of trust boards’ financial reports. “This is an embarrassment for Jeremy Hunt and shows the scale of the financial challenge in the NHS,” said Jonathan Ashworth, Labour’s shadow health secretary. “After ending the last financial year with a record deficit, we were told that NHS trusts would get their deficits down to £250m. These projections show that target lies in tatters, with the true deficit likely to be triple that.” The £850m is even bigger than the £550m-£580m overspend that some NHS leaders have said is the most the service can afford to overspend by this year without risking major financial problems. However, NHS Improvement, the health service’s financial regulator, has already warned that a figure as high as £550m would make management of the overall NHS financial position very risky. Missing the £250m target by as much as £600m could make it more difficult for Hunt to balane the Department of Health’s budget for this year. It would also raise uncomfortable questions about the effectiveness of the tough measures he has pushed through to try to get the NHS’s finances back on track, such as limits on the amounts trusts can pay for temporary doctors and nurses from employment agencies. NHS finance experts argue that the true scale of the NHS’s likely overspend in 2016-17 will be even greater as trusts are receiving £1.8bn in emergency funding this year from a sustainability and transformation fund (STF) to help cover huge overspends incurred last year. If that turns out to be the case – and HSJ’s projection proves accurate – the real deficit run up by trusts could be as much as £2.65bn. A record £2.45bn overspend was posted last year. NHS England and NHS Improvement agreed last month that what they call the provider sector’s overspend for 2016-17 must be no more than £580m and reiterated their determination for it not to exceed £250m. HSJ found that after the first six months of 2016-17 – and before money from the STF was factored in – providers had overspent by £1.56bn, a slight improvement on the deficit of £1.61bn seen after the first half of the previous year. Sally Gainsbury, a senior policy analyst at the Nuffield Trust thinktank, said: “If the forecast deficit is £850m now, then it seems like it’s only going to get worse throughout the rest of the year. Clinical commissioninggroups have been forced to hold back around £800m of their allocations this year, the 1% contingency fund, in case of overspending by trusts. And it looks as though the provider deficit will wipe that out completely.” But Chris Hopson, the chief executive of NHS Providers, which represents trusts, said: “There is a well-established plan to eliminate the provider sector deficit. Thanks to huge effort across all trusts, that plan is largely being delivered and is broadly on track. “Our members tell us they will have to work even harder in the second half of 2016-17 if they are to successfully manage the significant risk in delivering the required year-end figure of £580m”.
